title: Is it the end of Fortnite? Why the game has crashed and when it will be back online
text:
The video will start in 8 Cancel

Get the biggest daily news stories by email Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email

Social media feeds are flooded with stories about Fortnite and its mysterious ‘black hole’.

The popular game crashed last night, leaving players unable to access the game and only able to see a black hole on their screen.

Strangely, Epic Games, the developer behind Fortnite, has also deleted all of the tweets from the Fortnite Twitter page, leaving only a livestream of the black hole.

While the reason for the crash remains unclear, several theories are circulating online ranging from Elon Musk deleting the game to Epic Games preparing to launch Chapter 2.

Here’s why we suspect Fortnite has crashed, as well as when it’s likely to be back online.

Have you been affected by the Fortnite outage? Email webnews@mirror.co.uk

(Image: Epic Games)

Has Fortnite been deleted entirely?

Fortnite went down just as the Season X event was scheduled to begin at 19:00 BST (14:00 EST).

Since then, the game has been unaccessible online, with players being met by a strange black hole when trying to play.

Strangely, Epic Games, the developer behind Fortnite, has also deleted all tweets from the Fortnite Twitter page, leaving only the live stream.

This has led many baffled players to believe that Fortnite has been deleted entirely.

One user tweeted: “Yo I think Fortnite is actually gone. Like they deleted the game,” while another added: “They actually deleted Fortnite #RIPFortnite.”

Thankfully, this is very unlikely to be the case, and instead, we predict that the outage is in preparation for Fortnite Chapter 2.

Has Elon Musk deleted Fortnite?

Elon Musk appears to have hinted he could be responsible for the Fortnite blackout with a cryptic tweet.

The Tesla and SpaceX CEO has retweeted a fake news article from 2018, which claims Musk bought and deleted Fortnite ‘to save these kids from eternal virginity.’

At the time, Musk tweeted the story with the caption ‘Had to be done ur welcome.’ He has now retweeted it, simply writing ‘Haha.’

Thankfully his tweet is clearly made in jest, and has had some hilarious replies.

The Fortnite News account replied: “God damn it, Elon,” while professional Fortnite player Hogman added: “Alright fine you win this time, but you have to hire all of the pro players that are now jobless.”

Why has Fortnite crashed?

The outage is likely simply hype for the release of the 11th season of Fortnite, widely referred to as Fortnite Chapter 2.

This wouldn’t be the first time that Epic Games has pulled such a stunt.

(Image: Epic Games)

At the end of season seven, players noticed large cracks forming in the ground of the island, and eventually this formed a big volcano - marking the start of season eight.

Mirror Online has contacted Epic Games for comment.

When will Fortnite be back online?

While Epic Games has remained tight-lipped about when the game will be back online, rumours suggest that there are still few days to wait.

Dataminer, Lucas7yoshi, has delved into code of the game, and discovered an end time for the outage.

His findings suggest that Fortnite will be back online at 09:00 BST (04:00 EST).

However, he tweeted: “I really doubt they really going to make people not play for 4 days or whatever straight but it’s Epic lmao. Take it as you will.”

Are Fortnite skins safe during the outage?

Many fans are panicking that their precious skins may have been lost in the process.

Skins are graphics which can be used to change the appearance of a character in the game, and typically cost between £6 and £20.

Speaking to Mirror Online, concerned mother Kayla Williams said: “My son is heartbroken, he’s spent a massive £3,000 on this game since he started playing in season2.

“What are Epic going to do? People saying the game has ended for good so do we get full refunds on the money we spent because no game means no nothing so we lose out!”

Thankfully, PlayStation has confirmed that any items bought in the game are secure during the outage.

The Ask PlayStation Twitter account explained: “Please be assured that your inventory items and V-Bucks are secure during the Fortnite Blackout.
description: The reason for the Fortnite crash remains unclear, but several theories are circulating online about the outage
